6.28.19  12:38 pm   Hey Bill. I've started studying jazz piano this year. It's something I've always wanted to do (I have decent piano skills, but never took it very seriously). I'm extremely lazy and my teacher is also useless, so I haven't been making half as much progress as I could have. I've come to realize that I'm never motivated to practice, and I've been wondering if I really like jazz all that much. I'm still more interested in singing, producing and arranging in other genres (things I've done before), so I could prioritize that next year.

     why not prioritize it now?

      I've especially grown an interest in guitar-based music (and find myself listening to it more than jazz), and maybe learning to play the guitar. But at the same time, I feel like I just need to push through, because like I said I've wanted to do this for a long time, I really look up to jazz musicians, and I need to finish what I've started cause I can't keep doubting my goals and not working to accomplish something... Any advice? I'm 19 btw

     doing something that you don't really want to do ..... usually doesn't work out that well. if you are doing things you really really want to do, you tend to get superpowers

6.28.19  11:10 am   5.3.19  3:00 pm This isn't quite right. Entire songs can be in 2/4 and have a strong 2/4 feel - example https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TOypSnKFHrE

     i strongly disagree, assuming the tempo is fast (200). i strongly believe Last Night by the strokes to be in 4/4, and for the quarter note to be where the guitar *strokes* are (fast.) if you are calling that the eighth note, then i guess 2/4 would be preferable for good bar size, but i feel very strongly that the guitar stroke should be the quarter note and it's in 4. similar to 'are you gonna be my girl' by Jet, or 'walkin on sunshine', or 'can't hurry love', etc etc

6.28.19  10:06 am   bill since you are the most talented musician i know, can you tell me what happens here? https://youtu.be/UydrranrPaI at 0:22 there is a chord that feels like a common chromatic thing but it's different.

     Cmaj9. the reason it sounds wild is because the song is in C minor

      p.s: holyshit the questions page is getting crazy! what the hell was 6.26.19  7:39 pm lol

     that would be someone asking about chord technique, but they happen to be one of those people that thinks you should always play a chord in each hand, and my head momentarily exploded. also the learning approach they were taking seemed to be the kind of approach you would take if you were unable to hear the sound of the instrument. so i lost my mind briefly, i am sorry about that

6.28.19  8:27 am   you said you we
re going to change the editing software you're currently using (I won't specify but I'm fairly sure I have worked it out correctly). If so what to?

     one of the good things about this transition is that it has made me more aware that the main software i was using is something that actually should be more of the final step. at this point, it is more important for me to have more animation centered software. for many years i've been kind of attempting to do animation on software that really doesn't do animation

      I would go for either final cut pro 10 or premier.

     subscription pricing makes me want to jump off a building. but then again, the transition from fcp7 to fcpX invokes a very high amount of anger and bitterness. fcpX just feels so much like it's made for family vacation videos. even though i know it is very powerful (probably even more), it's just incredibly hard to escape the feelings of anger over the fact that the software you've used for 10 years has been deleted and replaced with something completely different with the same name. like they could have at least used a different name (iMovie Pro would be the perfect name). were they actually trying to trick someone?

      I know you can replicate your style on any editor, but I spoke to a guy who did a really good replication of your editing style on FCPX. Also, when you make your text, what effects do you use,

     i think i've used all of them at some point, but it's a lot of custom made tricks

      I technique i use when i try and make editing like yours is to create multiple copies of one word/sentence in slightly different places, and use different blending modes on them, i also animate it by adjusting parameters on a setting i have called earthquake. Could you help me, I'd really appreciate it.

     the thing about earthquake effects that always bothered me is you can't slow down the frame rate it uses. i think it always looks like crap at the full frame rate. actually i was never using the 'pro' version, i was using 'express' this entire time. maybe the pro version had a speed adjustment for it. but my process for dealing with the earthquake thing was to actually to export and re-import and then speed adjust to 25%. and if i have multiple words appearing to be timed properly, i would make the sequence, increase speed to 400%, export and reimport, put on the effect, then export and reimport again, then speed adjust to 25%. but usually with that i use 2 different layers, 2 separate earthquakes, and also use overdrive on one of them (that also requires the speed adjustment trick, because it seems to look like crap on full frame rate, example, see 'print out my feelings') and then also use blend modes between the 2 layers, usually difference for that one. and then juggle it around until it's good. then sometimes export and re import that. actually, starting in mid 2015 or so, exporting and re-importing was kind of my secret weapon for getting things that look like they're way beyond the capabilities of the program. that's true for a lot of art forms. you can do it with sound too. put a bunch of stuff on something, then export it and reimport it, then mess with it more. then export and reimport that and mess with it more. that's really the trick for getting the 'how did they do that' look

6.28.19  5:10 am   6.26.19  7:39 pm when i say G-Bb-D-F-Bb-C-D-F I really mean a voicing made of those notes bottom up, not each chord per letter.

     i know

      I was gonna write g-bb-f-d-bb-c-d-f but b for flat with non capital letter felt b for ti felt weird. I dont know if that makes more or less sense. And i did call Gb7 something wrong. I think its the Gmin7 with a "Bb add9" on top. so really a Gmin7 add11 with doubled 5th and 7th,  but revisitting it it should be a Bb something, as so the F something should really be a Ab something. and yes i do agree these are separate universes, but i wont let that excuse me from doing things in a perceivably wrong way(regardless of how thick i want my supersaws to sound). I get too sidetracked for beefiness that I may be overdoing the voicings and cluttering the arrangement (and missing the tonal center). Highly truly appreciate you taking your time to go over my rant and bring obje ctivity.   Now I have another point of view(and way more experienced) on my voicing approach or atleast cataloguing.  Sometimes it feels like im working on a vacuum but im super grateful and lucky to be able to bounce these things with a way more experienced skillster to atleast have a sense of where the needle might be pointing as opposed to letting my subjectivenes or missfocus from sidetracking me into a least-ideal place. I hope my follow up made more sense and had less mistakes at essential points. . So the 2 chord thing i was describing once i take your advice into consideration would be something like Ab bass (the F at the bottom was really unnecesary, its really some sort of Ab) with right hand doing g-bb-eb, and then going to G bass with f-g-bb-d on right hand.

     ah, much more comfortable

     How do you chose what to leave out when using many tensions on chords?

     experience, knowing the songs, knowing what sounds happen when you use different combinations of notes. the only way to really learn is to spend a lot of time with the instrument, a lot of time with songs, and general life experience. you will even find yourself gaining experience in stores, when you hear something on the radio

      Or it's a feel-along excercise with the theory behind the played voicings being an afterthought to analyze what was done? Upon yet ano ther revision my last version would be Ab (207.65) and on right hand g(392)-bb-c=eb which would translate to Abmaj7add9, and then for second chord Bb on bass (233) and then on right hand f(349)-bb-c-d. which would be a Bbadd9. Does it sound like a more balanced voicing?

     that seems great but very much on the high side. your bass notes are around middle C. this is cool, but if you are generally in the meat of the arrangement, your bass notes are going to be an octave lower (probably 2) and the right hand parts would be maybe half an octave lower. i'd say a nice happy range for your first chord (speaking in Hz again, cuz it's the only way to truly say which octaves we're using) Ab 52, and chord would start from Bb233 and up. a good range for the other one would be Bb 58, and C D F starting from middle C and up.

      I did have a weird keys patch where i was jamming with it but going to a normal keyboard sound makes it clearer to hear what im doing instead of letting the reverb disguise the sound. It seems like by your description your instinct would be to go for bass on left and guide tones (3rd and 7th) on right and then alter from there? 

     that's always cool, if you don't know the song yet and specifically what it needs where. also it's good to practice shuffling the range around so the chord/harmony generally is situated around the middle C range. that's just where all the harmony wants to be. i think the more music you check out, the more you will find that that's almost always where the actual harmony is taking place. you may have many instruments helping out, but there are never actually that many different notes being played. the harmonic content is really usually in the middle C range and slightly above. that's just something that i've found over time. when you hear a dense arrangement with a lot of instruments, i think you'd be amazed to find out that there still aren't that many different notes being played, there will be a lot of instruments playing the same notes (layering)

In one of your reality vids from 2011, you said that in the past you've thought that there was a way to get songs perfect, and you followed that up by saying that "perfect is invisible" and that it's "perfectly empty, abscent, etc.". I'm not quite sure what you meant by that..
By "perfect is invisible", did you mean that perfection exists merely as a concept/ doesn't exist in the real world?

     no

     Because that's what I got from it.
Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, I'd really like to hear your explanation/take on that phrase of yours.
